document.docAuthor: Viraktamath, C. A. & Anantha Murthy, H. V.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genera Hishimonus Ishihara and Litura Knight (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) from the Indian subcontinent with description of new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the genera Hishimonus Ishihara and Litura Knight (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) from the Indian subcontinent with description of new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
(Modified from
Knight ( 1970 a)
. Only female sex of
H. benglensis (Distant)
and
H. apricus (Melichar)
are known)

paragraph.keyLead: 1 . Aedeagal shafts with one pair of basal processes ( Figs 52 , 84 )................................................. 10
- Aedeagal shafts without pair of basal processes ( Figs 58, 69 )................................................... 2

2 . Apices of aedeagal shafts broad, either rounded or truncate (
Figs 144
, 171 ), but not filiform.......................... 3

3 . Apices of shafts tightly curved mesally (
Fig. 182
)......................................... ..
H. sonapaharensis Rao

- Apices of aedeagal shafts not so curved mesally (
Figs 142
, 171 )................................................. 4

- Aedeagal shafts not triangularly expanded subapically (
Figs 93
, 156 )............................................. 7

6 . Aedeagal shafts strongly abruptly tapered in lateral view beyond triangular expansion and concavely excavated (
Fig. 79
).........................................................................................
H. concavus Knight

- Aedeagal shaft abruptly narrowed and strongly recurved in lateral view without concave excavation (
Fig. 110
).....................................................................................
H. gillespiei Dai, Fletcher & Zhang

- Aedeagal shafts in lateral view not forked (
Fig. 59
).........................................
H. acuminatus
sp. nov.

8 . Aedeagal shafts each with a short, lateral, dorsally directed process at level of gonopore, apex appearing bifurcate ( Figs 91, 93 )......................................................................................
H. dividens Knight
- Aedeagal shafts without process at level of gonopore (Figs 97, 156 ).............................................. 9

9 . Aedeagal shafts tapered distad of gonopore (
Fig. 154
)...........................................
H. nielsoni Knight

- Aedeagal shafts tapered at level of gonopore ( Figs 69, 70 ).......................................
H. arcuatus Knight

11 . Aedeagal shafts shorter than length of basal processes (
Figs 134, 136
)..........................
H. longisetosus
sp. nov.

12 . Basal processes arising very close to adjacent shaft (
Figs 52
, 202 ).............................................. 13
- Basal processes arising between but slightly distant from base of shaft ( Figs 84 , 97, 190 )............................ 14

13 . Aedeagal shafts in lateral view broadest subapically (
Fig. 203
)....................................
H. thapai
sp. nov.

- Aedeagal shafts in lateral view, broad at base and tapering distally (
Fig. 51
).........................
H. aberrans Knight

14 . Basal processes arising anterad of shafts on dorsal apodeme (
Figs 221, 222
)..................... ..
H. zeylanicus
sp. nov.

15 . Aedeagal shafts each with subapical mesal rounded lobe in posterodorsal view and apical thin filamentous process (
Fig. 84
)......................................................................................
H. distinctus
sp. nov.

- Aedeagal shafts without subapical rounded lobe in posterodorsal view; apical process when present thicker (Figs 97, 192 )...................................................................................................... 16

16 . Posterior lobe of pygofer not spiculate (
Fig. 54
); aedeagal shaft in lateral view, triangular subapically, apex gradually tapered (Fig. 98 )...............................................................................
H. dwipae
sp. nov.

- Posterior lobe of pygofer strongly spiculate (
Fig. 186
); aedeagal shafts in posterior view with inner margins diverging, slightly convexly rounded subapically and in lateral view abruptly tapered (Fig. 192 ).......................
H. spicans
sp. nov.
